en.cannot create topology: Unable to create topology for flow
en.restart tooltip: Restart the execution from the {state} task
en.restart confirm: Are you sure you want to restart execution {id}?
en.restart change revision: You can change the revision that will be used for the new execution.
en.replay from task tooltip: Create a similar execution starting from task {taskId}
en.replay from beginning tooltip: Create a similar execution starting from the beginning
en.replay confirm: Are you sure you want to replay this execution {id} and create a new one?
en.replay the execution: Replay the execution {executionId} for the flow {flowId}
en.change state confirm:
Are you sure you want to change the task run state for the {task} task in execution {id}?
It will then restart the execution from the next task and restart the parent execution if any.
en.change queue confirm: Are you sure you want to change the queue state for the execution {id}?

WARNING: The flow will be marked as WARNING.
The next tasks will be executed.
The error tasks will be executed.
FAILED: The flow will be marked as FAILED.
No other task will be executed.
The error tasks will be executed.
SUCCESS: The flow will restart as this task was successful.
All the blocked tasks will be executed.
The flow will be in a SUCCESS state if all task runs are successful.
RUNNING: The flow will restart and will execute all next tasks.
All blocked tasks will be executed.

en.replay execution description: This will create a new execution based on the selected execution.
en.change execution state confirm: Are you sure you want to change the state of the execution {id}?
en.killed confirm: Are you sure you want to kill execution {id}?
en.resumed confirm: Are you sure you want to resume execution {id}?
en.pause title:
Pause execution {id}.
Note that currently running tasks will still be processed, and the execution will have to be resumed manually.
en.pause confirm: Are you sure you want to pause execution {id}?
en.unqueue title:
Are you sure you want to Unqueue execution {id}?

Note that it will not obey the flow concurrency limit, so more executions could be running than the allowed limit.
en.unqueue title multiple:
Are you sure you want to Unqueue {count} executions?

Note that it will not obey the flow concurrency limit, so more executions could be running than the allowed limit.
en.unqueue confirm: Are you sure you want to unqueue execution {id}?
en.force run tooltip: Force the execution to run. It can creates duplicate task executions, if possible use another action.
en.force run confirm:
Are you sure you want to force run execution {id}?

WARNING: force running an execution is not guaranteed and may create duplicate task runs.

The following transitions will be done:
  • CREATED tasks will be moved to the running state.
  • RUNNING tasks will be re-submitted.
  • QUEUED tasks will be un-queued
  • PAUSED tasks will be resumed.

security_advice.title: Protect your instance
security_advice.content: Enable basic authentication to protect your instance.

en.execution-warn-deleting-still-running: We strongly recommend that you cancel this action and kill any ongoing executions first. Deleting non-terminated executions can lead to concurrency issues, flow dependency management inconsistencies, and zombie processes on your instance, which can degrade system performance. Make sure you fully understand these risks before proceeding with the deletion.

tour.title: Take a product tour
tour.text: Choose your use case and follow a step-by-step guide to learn Kestra's features and capabilities. ❤️

tutorial.title: Tutorial
tutorial.text: * Video Tutorials * Documentation * Blueprints

help.title: Need help?
help.text: Ask any question in our Slack community. If you are stuck, we are here to help you. ✋

pluginPage.title1: Plugins are building blocks for your workflows.
pluginPage.title2: Search for tasks and triggers to build your flow.

fields.editor_folding_stratgy: Automatic Code Folding in the Editor
fields.editor_hover_description: Hover on property to see description
fields.environment_name_tooltip: This environment name is set from the config but can be changed.

localization.label: Language and Region
localization.note: Note that this setting is used for displaying date and time properties in the UI. To schedule your flows in a timezone different than UTC, make sure to set the timezone property on the Schedule trigger in your flow code or your plugin defaults.

save.label: Save
save.unsaved_warning: You have unsaved changes. Do you want to save them before leaving?

secrets.title: Upgrade your Secrets Management
secrets.message: The Enterprise Edition (EE) lets you add, edit, or delete secrets directly in the UI—no instance restarts needed. Organize secrets by namespace with granular RBAC permissions, and inherit them from parent to child namespaces. EE integrates with secrets managers like HashiCorp Vault, AWS Secrets Manager, Azure Key Vault, Google Secret Manager, and Elasticsearch. Set up dedicated backends per namespace, tenant, or instance to isolate secrets across teams, or enable read-only secrets stored in external vaults. Secrets stay encrypted at rest and in transit. Optional caching reduces API calls, and audit trails log all access.
secrets.detected_env: Here are secret-type environment variables identified at instance start-time:
secrets.empty_env: You don't have any Secrets in your environment yet.

add_env.first: Encode the secret value in Base64
add_env.second: Set an environment variable named SECRET_<MY_SECRET_KEY> with the encoded value.
add_env.third: Restart your Kestra instance so the secret is loaded.

apps.title: Build custom Apps with Kestra
apps.message: Apps in Kestra Enterprise Edition allow you to build custom UIs that interact with Kestra workflows from outside the platform. This feature lets you use your workflows as a backend for custom applications, enabling non-technical users to submit data through forms or resume paused workflows awaiting approval.

tests.label: Tests
tests.title: Ensure Reliability with Every Change
tests.message: Verify the logic of your flows in isolation, detect regressions early, and maintain confidence in your automations as they change and grow.

assets.label: Assets
assets.title: Bring every dataset, service, and dependency into view.
assets.message: Assets connect observability, lineage, and ownership metadata so platform teams can troubleshoot faster and deploy with confidence.

IAM.title: Manage Users through IAM with SSO, SCIM and RBAC
IAM.message: Kestra Enterprise Edition has built-in IAM capabilities with single sign-on (SSO), SCIM directory sync, and role-based access control (RBAC), integrating with multiple identity providers and letting you assign fine-grained permissions for users and service accounts.

tenants.title: Manage Workflows in Isolated Tenants
tenants.message: Kestra Enterprise Edition supports multi-tenancy, giving you fully isolated environments for different teams or projects, each with its own resources such as dedicated worker groups or secrets and internal storage backends.

audit-logs.title: Track Changes with Audit Logs
audit-logs.message: Kestra Enterprise Edition logs every activity with robust, immutable records, making it easy to track changes, maintain compliance, and troubleshoot issues.

instance.title: Manage Infrastructure Across Your Instance
instance.message: Kestra Enterprise Edition provides an operational dashboard to help you observe the health of your platform and track the uptime metrics of all services such as a.o. Workers, Schedulers, and Executors. From the same page, you can also create Announcements to notify your users about planned downtime, and you can enter a maintenance mode which temporarily puts all services and workflow executions into a paused state to perform an upgrade.

blueprints.title: Add Custom Blueprints
blueprints.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, you can create custom Blueprints only available to your organization. You can use them as best-practices templates to share, centralize, and document commonly used workflows in your team.

edit.title: Upgrade Your Namespace Management
edit.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, namespaces provide advanced isolation and governance of secrets, variables, and plugin defaults at scale. Administrators can configure custom secrets managers, isolated storage backends, dedicated worker groups, and fine-grained permissions on a per-namespace basis. This ensures that secrets, variables and plugin configurations remain secure and easy to maintain across different teams and projects.

secrets.title: Manage Secrets in a Secure Way
secrets.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, you can store and control secrets at the namespace level, minimizing risk and ensuring each team's credentials remain isolated. Thanks to the nested hierarchy, you can also configure credentials in a parent namespace, and they will be inherited by all child namespaces. Support for dedicated secrets managers and fine-grained namespace-level permission settings further strengthens security and compliance.

assets.title: Centralize Asset Management
assets.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, Assets keeps a live inventory of resources that your workflows interact with. These resources can be database tables, virtual machines, files, or any external system you work with.

variables.title: Centrally Govern Your Variables
variables.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, you can define and manage namespace-level variables to eliminate repetitive configurations across flows. These variables ensure consistency, simplify configuration updates, and can be easily referenced by any task or trigger for cleaner, more maintainable workflows.

plugin-defaults.title: Standardize Configuration with Plugin Defaults
plugin-defaults.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, you can set namespace-specific plugin defaults, reducing the need for duplicated setup in each flow. This central plugin governance enforces consistent configurations, allows secure referencing of secrets or variables, and simplifies maintenance of your workflows.

history.title: Manage Revision History in One Place
history.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, you can manage revision history of your Namespaces

audit-logs.title: Track All Changes in One Place
audit-logs.message: In Kestra Enterprise Edition, you can view namespace-level audit logs with detailed diffs, giving you a clear history of who changed what and when across all resources.

welcome.headline: Build and run your first workflow in minutes
welcome.guided_description: Learn how to create and run your first flow with guided steps.
welcome.self_serve_description: Go directly to the editor and build your own flow.

flow_basics.title: Flow basics
flow_basics.description:
In Kestra, a flow is the core orchestration unit. You define it in YAML with metadata and ordered tasks.

Review the example structure below, then continue to build it step by step.

add_id.title: Add flow id
add_id.description:
The ID is the unique name of your flow, so you can find it, run it, and reference it consistently.

Now add id at the root level.

add_namespace.title: Add namespace
add_namespace.description:
The Namespace is the folder-like grouping that organizes flows by team, project, or environment.

Now add namespace at the root level.

add_input.title: Add an input
add_input.description:
Inputs are flow-level parameters that can be referenced inside tasks to dynamically control behavior at runtime.

Now add an input named name with type STRING.

add_log_task.title: Add first task
add_log_task.description:
Tasks are the units of work your flow executes, defined as an ordered list of steps. Each task needs a unique id and a type. Kestra provides many task plugins for external systems; here we use a Python Script task.

The {{ ... }} syntax is a Pebble expression, used to reference variables dynamically at runtime, like {{ inputs.name }} from your flow inputs.

Now add the first task under tasks with id, type, and a script that prints a greeting.

save_flow.title: Save flow
save_flow.description: Saving persists your flow definition so it can be executed.

execute_flow.title: Execute flow
execute_flow.description: Executing starts a run of your flow with runtime input values.

view_logs_status.title: Check execution
view_logs_status.description:
Execution details show run status, timing, and task-level output logs.

Now open the execution details and click greet in the Gantt chart to see the logs.

edit_flow_from_execution.title: Return to Flow Editor
edit_flow_from_execution.description: You can jump directly from an execution back to the flow definition to iterate quickly.

add_cron_trigger.title: Add a cron trigger
add_cron_trigger.description:
Triggers can start runs based on schedules or external events (for example webhooks or MQTT messages).

Now add a cron schedule trigger so this flow runs every 5 minutes.

add_input_default.title: Set a default input value
add_input_default.description:
When a flow is triggered automatically, inputs still need values at runtime.

The name input was already created in the previous step, so there’s no need to add it again. Just set a default value for the existing name input.

save_flow_again.title: Save flow
save_flow_again.description: Your flow now has a schedule and a default input value for automatic runs.

background_runs_info.title: Scheduled runs
background_runs_info.description:
This flow will now execute in the background every 5 minutes.

You can navigate to the Executions overview from the left menu to monitor scheduled runs.

finish.title: You completed the First Flow tutorial
finish.description:
Great start. You created, executed, parameterized, and scheduled a flow.

Choose what to do next ...

actions.save_to_continue: Press Save in the top bar (right).
actions.execute_to_continue: 1. Press Execute in the top bar (right). 2. Provide a value for name. 3. Press Execute again in the modal.
actions.edit_flow_to_continue: Press Edit flow in the top bar (right).

editor_hints.build_intro: Build your first flow step by step.
editor_hints.step_4: # 4) Add tasks and your first Python task

cancel_modal.title: Cancel First Flow tutorial
cancel_modal.description: Do you want to cancel the First Flow tutorial?

validation.complete_step: You're close. Complete this step to continue.
validation.fix_yaml: There is a small YAML formatting issue. Fix it, then continue.
validation.add_id: Add a flow ID at the top. Example: `id: hello_flow`.
validation.add_namespace: Add a namespace at the top. Example: `namespace: company.team`.
validation.add_input_section: Create an `inputs` section with one input.
validation.add_log_task_section: Create a `tasks` section and add your first task.
validation.add_log_task_id: Give the task an ID, for example: `id: greet`.
validation.add_log_task_message: Add a `script` field to the task.
validation.add_log_task_pebble: Use a Pebble expression in the script so it uses your input value (for example: `inputs.name`).
validation.execute_flow: Run the flow once to continue.
validation.view_logs_status: Open the execution details and check the logs for `greet`.
validation.edit_flow_from_execution: Click `Edit flow` in the top bar to continue.
validation.add_cron_trigger_section: Create a `triggers` section with a schedule trigger.
validation.add_cron_trigger_cron: Add a cron expression, for example: `"*/5 * * * *"`.
validation.add_input_default_section: Go back to `inputs` and keep one existing input named `name` (do not add a second input).
validation.add_input_default_id: Keep the existing input ID as `name`.
validation.add_input_default_defaults: Add a default value for `name`, for example: `defaults: "Kestra"`.

announcements.title: You have no announcements yet!
announcements.content: Announcements allow you to notify your users about any changes or inform them about planned maintenance downtime. Simply select the announcement type, the date range for which it should be displayed, and write the announcement message.

kill_switches.title: You have no Kill Switches yet!
kill_switches.content: The Kill Switch feature provides a UI based mechanism to stop problematic executions. It replaces the CLI-only --skip-executions and --skip-flows commands with a comprehensive administration interface.

apps.title: You have no apps yet!
apps.content: Start building Apps to interact with Kestra from the outside world.

testSuites.title: You have no Tests yet!
testSuites.content: Add tests to validate quality and avoid regressions in your flows.

assets.title: You have no Assets yet!

ASSET.content: This asset has no upstream or downstream dependencies with flows or other assets.

plugins.title: No plugin defaults are set for this for this Namespace.
plugins.content: Read more about Concurrency Limits in our documentation.

triggers.title: Your flow doesn't have any Triggers.
triggers.content: Read more about Triggers in our documentation.

versionPlugin.title: You have no versioned plugin yet!
versionPlugin.content: Here you can manage all the plugins installed on your Kestra instance. Newly installed plugins may not be immediately available in all Kestra services, depending on the configuration of your instance.

panels.title: No panels are currently open.
panels.content: Open Flow Code or No-Code to start editing your flows, or select another panel (Topology, Documentation, Namespace Files, Blueprints, Context) for related features.

en.test-badge-tooltip: This execution was created by a Test

dashboards.empty: There are no results to be shown.

edition.label: Edit Dashboard
edition.id readonly: The property `id` cannot be changed — it's now set to its initial values. If you want to change it, you can create a new dashboard and remove the old one.

deletion.confirmation: Are you sure you want to delete {title} dashboard?

dashboards.chart_preview: Click on a chart source code to see its preview

subtitles.user: Secure your instance to get started.
subtitles.config: Here are the details of your configuration

form.password_requirements: At least 8 characters with 1 uppercase letter and 1 number.

validation.email_temporary_not_allowed: Temporary or disposable email addresses are not allowed
validation.incorrect_creds: Invalid username or password. Make sure your credentials are correct.
validation.config_message: Make sure to update your configuration to fix this error message

survey.company_size: What's your main goal with Kestra?
survey.use_case: What do you plan to use it for?

flow.title: AI Copilot
flow.prompt_placeholder: Enter instructions to create your Kestra flow. Example prompt: Create a flow that runs every Monday at 9 AM.

enable_instructions.header: AI Copilot hasn't been configured yet. To enable AI Copilot, add the following snippet to your Kestra instance configuration file (e.g. application.yml), replacing geminiApiKey with your actual key:
enable_instructions.footer:
Note: At this time, only Gemini is supported as the AI provider for Open Source Edition. For Enterprise Edition, please refer to the AI Copilot documentation for other model provider configuration.

Restart your Kestra instance after saving the configuration.

dashboard.prompt_placeholder: Ask a question about your data. Example prompt: Show me the success rate of my flows in the last 7 days.

playground.title: Playground
playground.run_task_info: Hover over any task in the Flow Code editor and click the "Run task" button to test your task.
playground.play_icon_info: You can also hit the Play icon in the No-Code or Topology views.
playground.confirm_create: You cannot run the playground while creating a flow. Launching a playground run will create the flow.
playground.tooltip_persistence: If you turn Playground off and back on, the information remains as long as you stay on the page.

en.draft_available: Draft change is available in the editor

search.asset_placeholder: Search by asset or flow or namespace...

filter.label: Label
filter.name: Name
filter.delete filter confirm: Are you sure you want to remove this filter?
filter.empty: You don't have any saved filter yet.
filter.save duplicate: A filter with this name already exists.

comparator_descriptions.EQUALS: Exact match - value must be identical
comparator_descriptions.NOT_EQUALS: Excludes exact matches - value must be different
comparator_descriptions.IN: Matches any value from a list of options
comparator_descriptions.NOT_IN: Excludes all values from a list of options
comparator_descriptions.GREATER_THAN: Numeric/date comparison - value must be larger
comparator_descriptions.LESS_THAN: Numeric/date comparison - value must be smaller
comparator_descriptions.GREATER_THAN_OR_EQUAL_TO: Numeric/date comparison - value must be larger or equal
comparator_descriptions.LESS_THAN_OR_EQUAL_TO: Numeric/date comparison - value must be smaller or equal
comparator_descriptions.STARTS_WITH: Text begins with the specified characters
comparator_descriptions.ENDS_WITH: Text ends with the specified characters
comparator_descriptions.CONTAINS: Text includes the specified characters anywhere
comparator_descriptions.REGEX: Advanced pattern matching using regular expressions

scope_log.label: Scope
scope_log.description: Filter by user or system logs

level.label: Level
level.description: Show logs at or above this severity

flows.last execution date: When the flow was last executed
flows.last execution status: Status of the most recent execution
flows.triggers: Triggers that can start the flow (e.g., schedule, event)
flows.revision: Current version number of the flow definition
flows.description: Text description provided for the flow

executions.namespace: Namespace to which the executed flow belongs
executions.revision: Version of the flow used for this execution
executions.inputs: Input values provided to the execution
executions.task-id: ID of the last task in the execution
executions.parent-execution: Parent execution ID that triggered this execution

kv.namespace: Logical grouping where the key-value pair is stored
kv.key: Unique identifier for the stored value
kv.description: Optional notes explaining the KV entry
kv.last modified: Timestamp of the most recent update

secrets.namespace: Logical grouping where the secret is stored

flow_triggers.next execution date: When the trigger will execute next

en.bulk delete triggers: Are you sure you want to delete {count} triggers?
en.delete trigger confirmation: Are you sure you want to delete trigger {id}? WARNING: deleting a trigger may lead to duplicate executions if the trigger is still active in a flow
en.delete revision confirm: Are you sure you want to delete revision {revision}?
